review.title: AI Evaluation: past, present and future
review.abstract: Artificial intelligence develops techniques and systems whose performance must be evaluated on a regular basis in order to certify and foster progress in the discipline. We will describe and critically assess the different ways AI systems are evaluated. We first focus on the traditional task-oriented evaluation approach. We see that black-box (behavioural evaluation) is becoming more and more common, as AI systems are becoming more complex and unpredictable. We identify three kinds of evaluation: Human discrimination, problem benchmarks and peer confrontation. We describe the limitations of the many evaluation settings and competitions in these three categories and propose several ideas for a more systematic and robust evaluation. We then focus on a less customary (and challenging) ability-oriented evaluation approach, where a system is characterised by its (cognitive) abilities, rather than by the tasks it is designed to solve. We discuss several possibilities: the adaptation of cognitive tests used for humans and animals, the development of tests derived from algorithmic information theory or more general approaches under the perspective of universal psychometrics.
histories: 34 pages. This paper is largely superseded by the following paper: "Evaluation in artificial intelligence: from task-oriented to ability-oriented measurement" Journal of Artificial Intelligence Review (2016). doi:10.1007/s10462-016-9505-7, \url{this http URL}. Please check and refer to the journal paper

metadata.title: AI Evaluation: past, present and future∗

sections.text: Keywords: AI evaluation, AI competitions, benchmark evaluation, sampling, close versus general AI, measurement, universal psychometry, Turing test.

sections.heading: 1 Introduction
sections.text: This is why we have gone so far that we are unable to help ourselves.

sections.heading: 2 Task-oriented evaluation
sections.text: We have successful applications in the fields of computer vision, speech recognition, music analysis, machine translation, text summarization, information gathering, robot navigation and interaction, automated vehicles, game, prediction, estimation, planning, automated deduction, expert systems, etc. (see e.g. [108]) Most of these application problems are specific, which implies that the goals are clear and that researchers can focus on the problem. This does not mean that we cannot apply more general principles and techniques to solve many of these problems, but that the task is sufficiently specific that the systems are specialized in these systems. For example, the robot navigation of a Mars robot can share some of the techniques with a driverless car on Earth, but the final application is extremely specialized in both cases. This specialization leads to an application-specific (task-oriented) assessment.

sections.heading: 2.1 Types of performance measurement in AI
sections.text: An application, as described above, can be characterized by a series of problems, tasks or exercises M. To evaluate each exercise, µ-M we can obtain a measurement R (π, µ) of the performance of the system π. However, measurements can be imperfect. Also, the system, the problem or the measurement cannot be deterministic. Consequently, it is common to work with the expected value of the performance of the system as E [R (π, µ).] The definition of M and R does not specify how we want to summarize the results if M has more than one problem. The most common approaches are: • Worst-case performance-1: Φmin Performance of the system performance as E [R, µ M E)] • Best-case performance: This performance max (M) = minµ-M E [R, µ) = minµ-performance of M]]] • Average performance of M, p.

sections.heading: 2.2 Evaluation by human discrimination
sections.text: In fact, it is such that most people who are able to survive themselves are also able to survive themselves. Most of them are able to survive themselves, in the way in which they live, in the way in which they live, in the way in which they live, in the way in which they live, in which they live, in which they live, in which they live, in which they live, in which they live, in which they live, in which they live, in which they live, in which they live, in which they live, in which they live, in which they live, in which they live, in which they live, in which they live, in which they live, in which they live, in which they live, in which they live, in which they live, in which they live, in which they live, in which they live, in which they live, in which they live, in which they live, in which they live, in which they live, in which they live, in which they live, in which they live, in which they live, in which they live, in which they live, in which they live, in which they live, in which they live, in which they live, in which they live, in which they live, in which they live, in which they live, that they live, in which they live, in which they live, in which they live, in which they live, in which they live, in which they live, in which they live, in which they live, in which they live, in which they live, in which they live, in which they live, in which they live, in which they live, in which they live, in which they live, in which they live, that they live, that they live, that they live, that they live, that they live, that they live, that they live, that they live, that they live, that they live, that they live, that they live, that they live, that they live, that they live, that they live, that they live, that they live, that they live, that they live, that they live, that they live, that they live, that they live, that they live, that they live, that they live, that they live, that they live, that they live, that they live, that they live, that they live, that they live, that they live, that they live, that they live,

sections.heading: 2.4 Evaluation by peer confrontation
sections.text: This year, it is so far that it only takes a few days to reach a decision in which an agreement is reached.

sections.heading: 3 Towards ability-oriented evaluation
sections.text: Most of them correspond to specific tasks and require task-oriented evaluation. However, other tasks that are not yet properly solved by AI technology are already evaluated in this way and will one day be successful. However, instead of AI applications that we think about AI systems, we see that there are some types of AI systems for which task-oriented evaluation of humans is not appropriate. For example, cognitive robots, artificial pets, assistants, avatars, smart houses, etc., are not designed to cover a particular application, but the user is expected to be tailored for a variety of tasks. To cover this wide range of (previously unseen) tasks, these systems need to have some skills, such as thinking skills, verbal skills, movement skills, etc. Hence, this includes, apart from task-oriented methods that we evaluate.

sections.heading: 3.1 What is an ability?
sections.text: We must first of all make it clear that we are talking about cognitive abilities, in the same way as in the previous section we referred to cognitive tasks. Some AI applications require physical abilities, especially in robotics, but AI is about how the sensors and actuators are controlled, not about their strength, consumption, etc. Once clarified, we can define a cognitive ability as a characteristic of individuals that allows them to function well in a range of information processing tasks. At first glance, this definition may look like a change of perspective (from problems to systems), but what we are now seeing is that the ability to get along without the ability is. In other words, the ability is necessary, but it does not have to be sufficient (e.g. spatial skills are not sufficient, but not sufficient, to drive a car). Also, the ability is assumed to cover a range of skills that we need to have a set of abilities without the ability to have the ability to show the abilities is.

sections.heading: 3.2 The anthropocentric approach: psychometrics
sections.text: An early concept that emerged was the distinction between knowledge and skills. For example, an "idiot savant" could have a lot of knowledge or would have developed a sophisticated ability over the years for some specific areas, but could be obtuse for other problems. On the contrary, a very capable person without prior knowledge could function well in a number of tasks, provided they are culturally fair. This distinction took several decades to consolidate. In some ways, this is similar to the narrow vs. general dilemma in AI.Psychometrics is about measuring cognitive abilities, personality traits and other psychological traits. Factors that differ from skills in principle are achieved through testing and further analysis through systematic approaches. Some factors were equated and named after existing abilities, while others are "discovered" and given new technical names.

sections.heading: 3.3 Evaluation using AIT
sections.text: This year, it has come to the point that there will only be one such event until such an event occurs.

sections.heading: 3.4 Universal psychometrics
sections.text: Figure 7 shows the fragmentation of the approaches seen in earlier sections, and accordingly the subject can be subjected. As we can see, this fragmentation arises from what kind of measurement we are interested in, but above all by the type of subject being measured. In [55] the term "universal test" is introduced, as a test that is applicable to "any biological or artificial system that exists at this time or in the future": human, non-human animals, machines, hybrids or collectives. "The use has been set high since the tests were supposed to function without knowledge of the subject, derived from computational principles, without prejudice (species, culture, language,...), no human intervention that produces an evaluation of meaning, practical and at any time that we have for the test, the higher reliability of the score). Note that in order to apply the same test to several subjects we are allowed to adapt the user interface, provided the characteristics and difficulty of the elements remain unchanged.

sections.heading: 4 Conclusions
sections.text: We have identified several problems and constraints, and we have found that there is still enormous scope for improvement in the way AI systems are evaluated, but this could play a more relevant role in the future. Imagining and evaluating skills is more difficult than imagining the task. We have argued that this requires integrating multiple perspectives that are currently dispersed in AI: psychometrics, AIT and comparative cognition. The different areas, philosophies, foundations, terminologies and the different types of subjects that can be combined with an integrated perspective as universal psychometry.

sections.heading: Acknowledgements
sections.text: This work was supported by the EU (FEDER) and the Spanish MINECO projects CONSOLIDER-INGENIO CSD2007-00022, TIN 2010-21062-C02-02 and TIN 2013-45732-C4-1-P, by the Generalitat Valenciana projects Prometeo / 2008 / 051 and PROMETEO / 2011 / 052 and the REFRAME project of the European Coordinated Research on Long-term Challenges in Information and Communication Sciences & Technologies ERA-Net (CHISTERA), funded by the respective national research councils and ministries (Ministo de Economi? a y Competitividad, code PCIN-2013-037, Spain). I thank the organizers of the Spanish Association of Artificial Intelligence Summer School in A Coruna, Spain, which took place in September 2014, for the opportunity to give a lecture on "AI Evaluation."

referenceMentions.context: What is the purpose of artificial intelligence (AI)? McCarthy’s pristine definition of AI sets this unambiguously: “[AI is] the science and engineering of making intelligent machines” [95].

Detterman, editor of the Intelligence Journal, wrote an editorial [24] where he suggested that Watson (the then recent winner of the Jeopardy! TV quiz [41]) should be evaluated with IQ tests.
Detterman, editor of the Intelligence Journal, wrote an editorial [24] where he suggested that Watson (the then recent winner of the Jeopardy! TV quiz [41]) should be evaluated with IQ tests.

The challenge is very explicit: “I, the editorial board of Intelligence, and members of the International Society for Intelligence Research will develop a unique battery of intelligence tests that would be administered to that computer and would result in an actual IQ score” [24].
Only computers passing the second level “could be said to be truly intelligent” [24].

Detterman was unaware that almost a decade before, in 2003, Sanghi and Dowe [109] implemented a small program (less than 1000 lines of code) which could score relatively well on many IQ tests, as shown in Table 4.

Notions such as ‘animat’ [142], machine-enhanced humans [20], human-enhanced machines [130], other kind of hybrids and, most especially, collective [105] of any of the former, suggest that the distinction between animals, humans and machines is not only inappropriate, but no longer useful to advance in the evaluation of cognitive abilities.

As a result, cognitive abilities are no longer what the cognitive tests measure, as in human psychometrics (adapting the (in)famous statement that intelligence is “what intelligence test measures” [11]), but they are properties that emanate from (general) classes of tasks, perfectly defined in computational terms.
, some results in [71] and [66] take a white-box evaluation approach).
, some results in [71] and [66] take a white-box evaluation approach).
This view of a cognitive ability is consistent with its association with a “class of cognitive tasks” [16] that must be ‘representative’ for the ability.
Typically, this is studied in a hierarchical way, starting with the so-called elementary cognitive tasks [16, page 11] (closely related to the notion of primary mental abilities of [126])” [59].

A theoretical analysis of ability interdependency, how they can develop and the notion of potential intelligence, are still in a very incipient stage [70, 56].

There can also be objections about how universal a test can be [31].
Item response functions and agent response functions [59] can be constructed empirically from the results and compared with the theoretical functions or any other information about Ω and M .

It is also crucial for the technological singularity once (and if) achieved [34], especially because some of the prophecies and forecasts disregard that the first thing to consider about the singularity is to have metrics to detect whether and where AI progresses towards it.

metadata.abstractText: Artificial intelligence develops techniques and systems whose performance must be evaluated on a regular basis in order to certify and foster progress in the discipline. We will describe and critically assess the different ways AI systems are evaluated. We first focus on the traditional task-oriented evaluation approach. We see that black-box (behavioural evaluation) is becoming more and more common, as AI systems are becoming more complex and unpredictable. We identify three kinds of evaluation: Human discrimination, problem benchmarks and peer confrontation. We describe the limitations of the many evaluation settings and competitions in these three categories and propose several ideas for a more systematic and robust evaluation. We then focus on a less customary (and challenging) ability-oriented evaluation approach, where a system is characterised by its (cognitive) abilities, rather than by the tasks it is designed to solve. We discuss several possibilities: the adaptation of cognitive tests used for humans and animals, the development of tests derived from algorithmic information theory or more general approaches under the perspective of universal psychometrics.
